conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, analyze the motion based on the acceleration-time graph.
The graph shows the particle's acceleration changes over time.
From t = 0 to t = t0/2, the acceleration is positive and linearly increasing from 0 to a0.
From t = t0/2 to t = t0, the acceleration is zero.
From t = t0 to t = 3t0/2, the acceleration is negative and linearly decreasing from 0 to -a0.
From t = 3t0/2 to t = 2t0, the acceleration is zero.
To find the velocity, integrate the acceleration with respect to time.
From t = 0 to t = t0/2, v(t) = a0 t0/4.
From t = t0/2 to t = t0, v(t) = a0 t0/4.
From t = t0 to t = 3t0/2, v(t) = 5a0 t0/4 - a0 t.
From t = 3t0/2 to t = 2t0, v(t) = 5a0 t0/4 - a0 t.
To find the position, integrate the velocity with respect to time.
From t = 0 to t = t0/2, x(t) = a0 t0^2/8.
From t = t0/2 to t = t0, x(t) = a0 t0^2/8.
The particle reaches its maximum distance from the starting point where the velocity is zero after the acceleration phase.
The particle is farthest from the starting point at t = t0.
